column1: thealienmademeslowdance 161029425662 "2017-05-24 19:05:07 GMT" http://thealienmademeslowdance.tumblr.com/post/161029425662/flavoracle-theitalianscrub-flavoracle "flavoracle: theitalianscrub:  flavoracle:  writing-prompt-s: A Genie offers you one wish
column2: and you modestly wish to have a very productive 2017. The genie misunderstands
column3: and for the rest of your life
column4: every 20:17 you become impossibly productive for just 60 seconds. â€œWell
column5: it was a nice day.â€ You kiss your sweetheart gently on the forehead and sigh as the last remaining seconds of 20:16 tick away.Â â€œSee you at 8:18
column6: â€ you say.Â  Then it happens. Every ounce of fatigue or hunger leaves your body. The face of your beloved is perfectly still
column7: their expression exactly the same. The ticking of the clock on the wall has stopped. Once again
column8: itâ€™s 20:17.Â  You stretch your arms and walk to the table with the homework for the three doctorates youâ€™re working on. The work is mentally stimulating and enjoyable
column9: but itâ€™s finished far too quickly. You check your pocket watch and see that not even one hundredth of a second has passed.Â  You knew it was too soon to be able to see any movement on the watch
column10: but you can never quite help yourself from looking early on every 20:17. Time to move on.Â  You clean your home
column12: then go outside and fix a noise that your car was making earlier that afternoon. (Oh how you already miss afternoons.) Then you go back inside
column13: boot up your computer (which magically speeds up to keep pace with you as long as youâ€™re in contact with it) and check for any new orders.Â  Youâ€™ve set up a website for the small business you started calledÂ â€œMagic Elf Services.â€ People in your area can pay a modest fee on your site to have different tasks and odd jobs done byÂ â€œThe Magic Elfâ€ at 8:17pm every day. It was a little slow to get started
column14: but word has spread and these days you have a steady stream of clients.Â  The money that comes in from the business is nice
column15: but youâ€™re mostly grateful that it gives you a clear list of things to do. You print off your updated list of clients
column17: and start making your way through the neighborhood with your to-do list.Â  Thereâ€™s the apartments down your street where several neighbors have hired you to tidy up
column19: and mop the floors. You do the windows too
column20: just to see if they notice. Thereâ€™s the large house across town that paid theÂ â€œMagic Elfâ€ to clean out the gutters. After the first dozen jobs are done
column21: you manage to stop looking at your pocket watch.Â  As near as youâ€™ve been able to determine in the past
column22: 20:17 seems to last for approximately one normal year. But itâ€™s not exact. For one thing
column23: itâ€™s hard to keep track ofÂ â€œtimeâ€ when everything but you has crawled to an almost total standstill. For another thing
column24: time seems to move differently depending on howÂ â€œproductiveâ€ your behavior is. One time you tried to spend all of 20:17 sitting at home in your pajamas
column25: but that was getting you nowhere
column26: so you eventually gave up and got busy. (Though you defiantly stayed in your pajamas the whole time.)Â  During 20:17 your body doesnâ€™t get tired
column29: or injured. Youâ€™re essentially tireless and immortal for the duration of theÂ â€œminute.â€ So sleeping or eating away your boredom has never really worked for you.Â  One of the houses on your list forgot to follow the instructions and leave a key for you to get in. At first you figure youâ€™ll just send them an email telling them to pay more attention and that youâ€™ll do the job tomorrow. Then you decide to go home
column31: and come back.Â  After finishing up all the jobs on your list
column32: you go into several other homes and small businesses in the area
column33: performing tasks you hope theyâ€™ll find helpful
column34: and leaving a hand-painted business card at each one. (The business cards donâ€™t contain your real name just in case somebody thinksÂ â€œThe Magic Elfâ€ should be subject to breaking and entering laws.)Â  Speaking of laws
column35: you head down to the local police station to pick up your case file. Youâ€™ve been in contact with a detective whoâ€™s been investigating corruption within their department
column36: and your ability to investigate unseen and get in almost anywhere between the ticks of the clock has proven invaluable. You see that theyâ€™ve also added five missing person cases to your file this evening
column37: which certainly raises your interest in the job.Â  You make your way through town gathering evidence
column38: and start making your way to the outskirts of town. Since you happen to be out that way (and youâ€™ve already solved three of the five missing person cases) you decide to swing by the stone castle youâ€™re building and do some more work there.Â  The castle walls stand about 20 feet right now
column39: but you know theyâ€™ll be much higher when youâ€™re done. Youâ€™re far from any roads and pretty safely tucked away
column40: so for now itâ€™s your little secret. Youâ€™ve been excavating and moving all the rock yourself
column41: which has been much easier than you first expected since your body doesnâ€™t get tired or sore. Youâ€™ve also got a nice system of tunnels going underneath the castle
column42: and you dig and build more of that network for a while.Â  All that time spent underground has left you feeling rather lonely
column43: so you walk back home to see the face of your sweetheart. Their facial expression has moved ever so slightly since you last saw them
column44: which is a comfort to you. Looking at them gets your imagination going and makes you dream up a story youâ€™d like to tell
column45: so you sit on your couch
column47: and write a book.Â  After you finish editing the last chapter for the third time
column48: you finally allow yourself to look at your pocket watch again. Three seconds have officially passed so far.Â  Itâ€™s gonna be a long 20:17.Â   Wow
column49: Dave. You managed to take a concept that seems nice on the exterior and make it into a real nightmare. This is some good stuff.  Which is EXACTLY why you should never trust a wish-granting djinn.Â  " False text

thealienmademeslowdance 160941998167 "2017-05-22 09:00:31 GMT" http://thealienmademeslowdance.tumblr.com/post/160941998167/avpd-and-how-we-control-anxiety "zella-rose: (Part of my ongoing series of posts on Avoidant Personality Disorder.) So in anxiety disorders
column2: there are â€œsafety behaviorsâ€ that are things you do to manage your anxiety. Like when people with social anxiety are around other people
column4: or stay in the bathroom longer than necessary
column6: or only  go somewhere with another person. See also: compulsions in OCD. Itâ€™s something you do while you are in the presence of your Feared Thing
column7: to make it less scary/more tolerable.Â  Itâ€™s like a buffer. But Iâ€™ve had a hard time figuring out what is the safety behavior in Avoidant Personality Disorder. So much of its actual presence in peopleâ€™s lives (or at least in mine) seems to be: â€œterrified of being seen/rejected by others.â€ And where you have anxiety
column8: you should also be seeing safety behaviors
column9: right? But itâ€™s not really talked about. Obviously you can just AVOID people as much as possible
column10: and not have to deal with it in the first place. (Like
column11: clearly. I myself am a shut-in
column12: because AvPD.) But what if youâ€™re actually in it
column13: facing this anxiety/threat? What do you do? How do you buffer the fear? To lower AvPD anxiety
column14: you de-escalate the intimacy.  I bet MOST of us have a kind of hierarchy of â€œhow scary/how close is this type of interaction.â€ And if something is too scary
column15: what do you do? Bump down the closeness a step. You stop touching
column17: put a barrier in between you; you reduce the level of contact
column21: to email. (This is my hierarchy; yours might be different.) If youâ€™re in a group and their scrutiny is freaking you out while you try to talk to someone
column22: you go off and talk alone. Or if being alone with someone is too scary
column23: you get somebody to go with you. Online
column24: maybe you size down the chat window or minimize it entirely between replies. You silence the notifications. You fullscreen something else over it. (Maybe you compulsively glance over to see if theyâ€™ve responded
column25: like I do.) If youâ€™re trying to share something about yourself
column26: maybe you choose to give it to them long-form all at once
column27: so you canâ€™t lose your nerve halfway through. Maybe you edit out select details that are Too Revealing
column29: too you. Maybe you only share it with them when youâ€™ve both agreed to discuss it immediately
column30: so it isnâ€™t hanging in the air between you. Itâ€™s about this: controlling how much access (ability to disturb) they have to you controlling what they get to see and monitoring how they react The â€œsafestâ€ situation is one where they have very little access to you; where you only allow them to see a bare minimum of personal details about you; and where you can watch and try to mitigate how they are responding to you/what they think of you. The most â€œunsafeâ€ situation is one where you canâ€™t control how much access they have to you (i.e. you live with them or see them every day
column31: you canâ€™t get away from their influence/moods/judgments
column32: or they have power over some aspect of your life) you canâ€™t control how much about you they get to see (i.e. no privacy
column33: no boundaries) and you canâ€™t monitor or affect how they react (i.e. they find out a secret of yours and then abruptly leave
column34: or they just wonâ€™t communicate their feelings with you at all
column35: or you arenâ€™t even aware of what they know until they confront you). (Okay
column37: I basically just described my entire relationship with my mom. So this theory may have overlap with codependency
column40: rather than being pure AvPD.) De-escalating intimacy = de-escalating trust. Youâ€™re reducing their ability to hurt you â€“ youâ€™re making â€œHow much I am forced to trust youâ€ as tiny and inert as possible. Which is very useful in a situation where the person is actually going to (or genuinely might) hurt you. But this eventual habit of lowering intimacy
column42: also means creating distance between you and people you might actually like to form a connection with. Once you are out of an unsafe situation
column43: this â€“ controlling how much access they have to you
column44: controlling what they get to see
column45: and monitoring how they react â€“ is no longer about managing a threat
column46: or danger. Itâ€™s about managing anxiety.  And here is what we know: Compulsions
column48: avoidance â€¦ anything we do to defend against anxiety
column49: is self-reinforcing. The more you do it
column50: the stronger the urge to do it next time. Thereâ€™s another thing: When you avoid every single instance of  interpersonal conflict
column51: you never get the chance to learn how to handle  it in a healthy way. So
column53: when you get into a normal
column55: or have to stand up for yourself
column56: or defend your  boundaries â€“ 2 things: You havenâ€™t built up the skills to handle it in a way  that feels safe
column58: youâ€™re super sensitized to conflict because itâ€™s rare. Conflict is  actually scary and feels out of control
column60: on top of your  pre-established fear. And that can be emotionally violent enough
column61: that it can actually be traumatizing or  re-traumatizing all on its own. This obviously isnâ€™t the whole story of AvPD. Itâ€™s a personality disorder
column62: not just an anxiety disorder. But I bet for some people
column64: this is a huge chunk of it. " False text
